msItem.author: Pietro Barozzi
msItem.title: De ratione bene moriendi
msItem.rubric: (fol. 1r) Petri Barrotii episcopi Bellunensis et Comitis in Librum de ratione bene moriendi prefatio ad Marcum Barbum Patriarcham Aquilegiensem Sanctę Romanę Ecclesię Cardinalem, Episcopum Praenestinum
msItem.incipit: Moyses in deserto Pharan cum iussu dei
(fol. 2v) Bk. I Mortem maximum esse terribilium
msItem.note: Bk. II beg. fol. 23; Bk. III, fol. 66v.
msItem.explicit: (fol. 95) et regnat Deus per omnia secula seculorum. Amen.
msItem.note: Pr. Venice, 1531, 'in aedibus Io. Antonii et Fratrum de Sabio', with other works of Barozzi, edited by Bernardino Scardeone. Pietro Barozzi (1441-1507) was Bishop of Belluno 1471-87. Marco Barbo, created a cardinal in 1467, was Patriarch of Aquileia from 1470 to 1491, and, according to Barozzi's preface, consecrated him as Bishop of Belluno.
There are some contemporary marginal notes.

extent.seg: iii + 99 leaves (fol. 82 is double, fol. i-iii, 97–8 are flyleaves)

supportDesc.collation: I original flyleaf, 1(10)-9(10), 10(6) (a leaf (fol. 91) inserted after 1). The bottom of fol. 91, including one line of the text, has been cut off

layoutDesc.layout: 32 long lines ruled with a hard point.

decoDesc.decoNote: On fols. 1r, 2v, 23r, 66v, faceted initials in blue, green, or plum on rectangular backgrounds with concave sides and bevelled corners in the same colours.
Smaller initials plain red or blue.
In the lower margin of fol. 1r on a delicately shaded blue background two standing putti support the Barbo arms, with a cross and cardinal’s hat above. (Pächt and Alexander ii. 560, pl. LII)

binding.p: 18th-cent. Italian binding in green morocco with gilt borders, in one of the styles used by the Abate Canonici. For patterns used cf. MSS. Canon. Bibl. Lat. 58; Canon. Class. Lat. 72 and 102; Canon. Misc. 184; Canon. Pat. Lat. 91.

history.provenance: With the Barbo arms and cardinal's hat on fol. 1 our MS. is almost certainly the dedicatory copy of this work presented to Cardinal Marco Barbo, patriarch of Aquileia, by Barozzi whilst bishop of Belluno, 1471–1487.

On fol. iii (original flyleaf) in a 16th-cent. hand is the note 'P. Eps. Aquen.' This probably was the note of a Bishop of Acqui in Italy: either Petrus Vorstius (Bishop 1534-49) or Petrus Faunus Costiciarius (1558-85).

The MS. belonged later to the Abate Matteo Luigi Canonici of Venice (1727-1805). Stuck in the front is a description of the MS. made after the death of Canonici with the shelfmarks 'Lib. 4 Scaf. 2' and 'no. 150'. Similar descriptions are found in other Canonici-Sneyd MSS.: see J. Mitchell in B.L.R. VIII, no. 3 (Feb. 1969), 134-5.
Acquired by the Revd. Walter Sneyd in 1835 and MS. 290 in 1837 Catalogue of his collection (pr. Sir T. Phillipps in Cat. MSS. Magnae Britanniae 1, 1850, p. 16).
James P. R. Lyell, 1871–1948: bought in March 1943 from Maggs Bros.: see their Cat. 672 (1939), no. 17; 687 (1940), no. 242; 713 (1942), no. 452A, with plate.
history.acquisition: Chosen as one of the hundred manuscripts bequeathed to the Bodleian by Lyell in 1948.

recordHist.source: A. C. de la Mare, Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts Bequeathed to the Bodleian Library Oxford by James P. R. Lyell (1971) Catalogue, p. 246 Catalogue, p. 247

revisionDesc.change: Incorporate all information from printed catalogue.
